Graphical abstracts Image, graphical abstract Keywords Kinetics n-hexane isomerization Hydroisomerization Ni-promoting effect Pt/HZSM-5 catalysts Introduction At presence, the study of the isomerization of linear paraffins into branched isomers has received widespread interest since isoparaffins have higher octane numbers than their linear analogs [1] and can replace harmful aromatic and olefin hydrocarbons in gasoline. The C5-C7-paraffin isomerization reaction is usually performed on bifunctional catalysts containing Pt or Pd on acidic supports such as various zeolites. In the work [2], the activity of platinum catalysts carried on ZSM-5, mordenite, and beta zeolites in the hydroisomerization of n-pentane were studied. It was reported that the activity of all catalysts is comparable, but the platinum catalyst supported on beta zeolite was characterized by the highest selectivity toward isopentane formation. In the works [3,4], the high activity of platinum catalysts on mordenite and Y-zeolites in the hydro-isomerization of n-hexane was noted. The comparison of platinum and palladium catalysts supported on zeolites was carried out in [5-9]. In [5], catalysts containing 1.0% Pt or Pd on beta zeolites were investigated in the hydroisomerization of C6-C8-n-paraffins and their mixtures. The dispersion degree of the Pt catalyst (73%) was almost 3 times higher than that of the Pd catalyst (25%), whereby the conversion of n-hexane was 18.7 and 7.7% on Pt-and Pd-catalysts respective. However, on both catalysts selectivity for the isohexanes formation was almost the same (94.5 and 94.2%) at 330 °C, 10 atm, and molar ratio H2/h-C6H14=14. The higher conversion of all the studied n-paraffins on Pt catalysts was attributed to their higher dispersion and high hydrogenation capacity [5]. At 290 °C, the differences in the benzene conversion between Pt and Pd catalysts were not large, but with increasing temperature, the difference became more significant (at 330 °C this value was 97.0% and 80.9% respectively for Pt and Pd catalysts). Catalysts containing 1.0% Pt or Pd and supported on mordenite, beta, and ZSM-5 zeolites were also studied in the hydro-isomerization of a mixture of C7-C8-paraffins in [6,7]. The activity of Pt catalysts supported on beta and ZSM-5 zeolites was close and significantly higher than that on Pt/mordenite. The formed amount of isoparaffins was highest on Pt/beta. The activity of Pd -catalysts supported on mordenite and beta was almost the same and 2 times higher than those on Pd/ZSM-5. However, the activity of Pt-catalysts was significantly higher than all Palladium catalysts. This was caused by higher hydrogenating-dehydrogenating ability and a high dispersion of Pt-catalysts, as reported in [5]. The comparison of the active of Pt- and Pd-catalysts supported on mordenite and mesoporous silicalites in the hydroisomerization of n-pentane showed that at 400 °C, the conversion and selectivity of isopentane formation on the 0.5% Pt/mordenite catalyst were respectively 40 and 49% versus 14 and 35% on the 0.5% Pd /mordenite catalyst at the same conditions [8]. At 10% conversion, the selectivity of isopentane formation was 92% on 1.27wt.% Pt catalyst and 68% on 0.79wt.% Pd-catalysts were found in [9]. The authors attribute the higher activity of Pt catalysts to the unfilled d-orbital of platinum in comparison with palladium. Bimetallic catalysts are increasingly showing their advantages. Adding the second metal significantly improves physical and chemical properties, activity, selectivity, as well as the stability of catalysts [10]. Besides, it also improves the reducibility as well as the dispersion of the main metal [11]. In most cases the bimetallic system is also exhibited higher coke-resistance than the original monometal system [12]. Promotion of 0.26% Pt/H-MOR catalyst with 0.5% Ni gives higher conversion and two-branch isomer selectivity while the cracking gas content is less than those of 0.26%Pt/ H-MOR catalyst [13]. The increasing activity of Pt-Ni/H-MOR was explained by the difference in the electronic properties of platinum in promoted and non-promoted catalysts. However, when the Ni content increased to 1.5%, the opposite result was obtained. In addition, the Pt-Ni/zeolite Y catalyst is also more active and stable in the hydrogenation of acetophenone than the Ni/zeolite Y one thanks to the interaction between Pt and Ni [14]. For Pt/HUY and Pt-Ni/HUSY catalysts with total Pt and Ni content of 1 – 2 wt.% it was found that Pt-Ni/HUSY sample with Ni/(Pt + Ni) ratio of 70-80% [15] or 60% [16] exhibited higher activity and selectivity of two-branches isomer than the Pt/HUSY catalyst in the reaction of n-hexane isomerization. The isomerization reaction kinetics of n-hexane has been studied by many authors [17-19]. Many kinetic models have been proposed, but the proposed kinetic models differ from different investigations. The role of hydrogen in the hydrogen-isomerization reaction also has not been consistent. This can be due to the diversity of the catalysts or /and the reaction conditions. At low pressure, hydrogen speeds up the reaction [20-23]. On 1% wt Pt/HY-catalysts for n-hexane isomerization at low n-hexane conversions (less than 10%), when it was possible to ignore the reverse reaction and the influence of the products, a fractional-rational kinetic equation was obtained [17]. In the kinetic equation the pressure of n-hexane was included in the numerator and denominator, meanwhile the partial pressure of hydrogen appears only in the numerator in the first order. This equation corresponded to a mechanism involving the dehydrogenation of n-paraffin at the platinum centers, the isomerization of olefin at the acid sites of the zeolite, and its further hydrogenation at the metal centers. A similar mechanism and kinetic equation were proposed for the isomerization of n-hexane at 250 °C on different zeolites such as mordenite, faujasite, and beta containing Pt catalysts [24] and on Pt-La deposited on faujasite catalyst [25]. For n-hexane hydroisomerization on palladium-based catalysts such as Pd/HZSM5, Pd-Ni/HZSM5, and Pd-Co/HZSM5 catalysts, the fractional-rational equations were proposed [26], where the partial pressure of hydrogen is included in both the numerator and denominator of the equations in 0.5 order. It is shown that the introduction of hydrogen increases the rate of isomerization. However, as the pressure changes, the kinetics of the reaction also change. When the total pressure reaches a certain value (20 atm and more), an increase in the partial pressure of the hydrogen will have the opposite effect, inhibiting the reaction [17, 19, 27, 28]. On the same catalyst Pt/HMOR8 the reaction order for hydrogen could change from negative at high pressure (30 atm) to positive at low pressure (1 atm), as found in the study [30]. The mechanism for n-alkane hydroisomerization over bifunctional catalysts has been extensively studied [30-33]. These studies all confirmed that the common mechanism was accepted for the isomerization of n-hexane at atmospheric pressure on Pt-based catalysts. This mechanism involves the following steps: Step 1: dehydrogenation of n-hexane to form n-hexene over platinum clusters; Step 2: adsorption of n-hexene on the zeolite acid site to form a surface-bound, linear alkoxide species; In step 3 this linear alkoxide species isomerizes into a branched alkoxide species; Step 4: desorption of the branched alkoxide to form a monobranched alkene and regenerate the acid site, and the last step (5) hydrogenation of the branched alkene on platinum clusters to generate mono-branched hexane undergoes. Meanwhile, on the Pd-based catalysts, the same reaction mechanism was proposed with a difference that the intermediate involved in the slow step is C6H13Z instead of n-hexene as in the mentioned above one for the Pt catalyst. In this paper, the effect of Ni additive on the properties and the activity of Pt/HZSM-5 catalyst as well as the kinetics and mechanism of n-hexane hydro-isomerization on the given catalyst are studied. Experimental The support for palladium catalysts was HZSM-5 prepared by the calcination of (NH4)ZSM-5 (CBV3024E, Zeolist International, United States) at 500°C for 3 h. The obtained H-ZSM-5 sample has a specific surface area of 353 m2/g and Si/Al ratio of 15. Monometallic catalyst (0.35 wt.% Pt) and a bimetallic catalyst (containing 0.35 wt.% Pt and 1.0 wt.% Ni) have active phase compositions that are close to optimal in terms of activity in the isomerization of n-hexane. The catalysts are obtained by classical impregnation under optimal conditions. The HZSM-5 support is impregnated from an aqueous solution of H2[PtCl6]•6H2O and Ni(NO3)2•6H2O[17]. The bimetallic catalyst was synthesized by sequential impregnations: the first, support was impregnated with an aqueous solution of nickel nitrate and then with the platinum salt solution. After the impregnation products were dried at 110°C (2 h) and 130°C (3 h), and then calcined at 400°C (2 h). Before performing experiments, the catalysts were reduced with hydrogen at 400°C for 2 h. Physicochemical properties of the catalysts were studied by the low-temperature N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction(XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR), and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). The specific surface area of the catalysts (S BET) was determined by nitrogen adsorption on an ASAP 2020V4.01 analyzer (Micromeritics, United States). The phase composition of the catalysts was determined by X-ray diffraction on an XD-5A diffractometer (Shimadzu, Japan) using CuKα radiation. Particles were sized using a JЕМ-1400 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan). Н2-TPR experiments were carried out using a ChemBET 3000 analyzer (Quantachrome, United States). The heating rate was 10о/min. The initial mixture consisted of 10.0% Н2 and 90.0% N2. Before TPR measurements, the oxidized samples were kept in flowing He for 2 h at 200°C and cooled to 30°C, and the temperature was then elevated to 900°C. The catalyst samples to be characterized by NH3-TPD were reduced at 400°C with a 10.0% Н2 + 90.0% N2 mixture for 2 h and were then cooled to 100°C in He flow. After NH3 adsorption and removal of physically adsorbed ammonia at 150°C for 1 h, the temperature was raised to 700°C at a rate of 10о/min. The steady-state kinetics of n-hexane isomerization was studied in the presence of hydrogen in a flow circulation system at atmospheric pressure and temperatures of 215–260°C. The partial pressure of n-hexane (Pn-C 6 H 14), hydrogen (PH 2), and intentionally added isohexane (Pi-C 6 H 14) was varied in the ranges of 33.3–137, 307–718, and 0–19.2 hPa, respectively. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 3500–56000 h–1. Under these experimental conditions, the n-hexane conversion (Х) varied between 0.12 and 0.75. The side reaction was cracking, and its proportion did not exceed 2.0%. The reaction mixture was analyzed on an Agilent 6890 Plus gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, United States) fitted with a flame-ionization detector and a capillary column (30m, 0.32mm, 6% cyanopropylphenyl 94% dimethylpolysiloxane stationary phase). The unsteady-state kinetics of n-hexane isomerization was investigated at atmospheric pressure in a small flowthrough unit having three independent lines. The unit was coupled with an MSKh-6 time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Russia). Transitional processes leading to a steady state were studied by the response method. Relaxation curves were obtained as a response to an abrupt change of the concentrations of reaction mixture components. The residence time, i.e., the ratio of the volume of the reaction system to the flow rate did not exceed 6 s, and this fact was taken into account in the construction of the relaxation curves. The following masses were registered: 2 (hydrogen), 43 (isohexanes), and 57 (n-hexane). In each experiment, only one substance was measured with a periodicity of 1 s. Under the conditions of our experiments, the process took place in the differential reactor regime. The experiments were conducted under the following conditions: n-hexane partial pressure, 66 hPa; H2: n-hexane molar ratio - 14.2; feed flow rate - 6 L/h; temperature - 250°C; catalyst weight - 1.0 g. Results and discussion Catalysts characterizations The X-ray diffraction pattern of the monometallic platinum catalyst and those of the Ni-containing bimetallic samples were similar and showed only peaks characteristic of HZSM-5 at 2θ = 7.9°,8.8°, 23.1°, 24.1°, and 29.1° (Fig. 1 ). The crystalline phases of Pt [34] and Ni oxide were not detected because of their low concentration or/and high dispersion. Crystallite dimension of HZSM-5 was calculated by Scherer equation at 7.9° [35] is shown in Table 1 . The results follows that the addition of platinum and nickel did not lead to changes the XRD pattern and the crystallite size of HZSM-5 varied in the narrow range of 30−32 nm. Table 1 shows the surface area (SBET), the particle size of the active phase obtained from TEM image (Fig. 2 ), and the acidity of platinum catalysts. As follows from these data, the introduction of Ni into the platinum catalyst leads to a reduction in the size of Pt-containing clusters. A similar phenomenon has been recognized in other studies [36, 37]. It was reported by Guczi [37], in bimetallic catalysts, the strong interaction of poor reducible metal (Ni) with the support, stabilizing the second metal phase, usually the precious metal, in a fine dispersion. A reduction of the specific surface area of the zeolites after Pt and Ni impregnation was expected due to the deposition of metallic particles on the pore mouth that block the access of nitrogen. Such coverage is in accordance with TEM results, which showed the average Pt particle size was 1.63 and 1.28 nm respectively for Pt and PtNi catalysts, while the pore size of ZSM-5 is 0.54–0.56 nm [38]. The Pt particle size is larger than the pore size of ZSM-5, so the Pt particles are located in the external surface. The results of TPD-NH3 for the studied samples are shown in Fig. 3 . As was shown in [26] for HZSM5 samples, it is difficult to estimate with high accuracy the concentration of weak acid centers by TPD-NH3 methods. Then, in the Table 1 the sum of medium and strong acid sites (NH3 desorption temperature > 280 °C) was shown. It can be seen that the introduction of Pt and Pt-Ni in HZSM-5 leads to a slight increase in the summary of medium and strong acidity in the samples. At the same time, the differences in acidity between the Pt and Pt-Ni catalysts are even smaller (Table 1). According to [39], the introduction of Ni up to 3.0% (wt.) in the Pt/HY catalyst did not affect its acidity, but for Pt/alumino-silicate catalyst the introduction of 5% (wt.) Ni led to the disappearance of strong acidity [40]. Fig. 4 shows the TPR-H2 diagrams of the studied catalysts and Ni(1%)/HZSM5. Curve 2 (Pt-HZSM5) has two peaks at 230 and 420°C, corresponding to the reduction of PtOx oxides (x =1 or 2) readily available and/or weakly bound to the support (first peak) and strongly bound or less accessible (second peak). This point of view is shared by the authors of [41], where deposited platinum catalysts with a close Pt content were studied. In [42], it was shown that after the reduction of platinum catalysts (0.15 and 0.46% Pt deposited on HZSM-5) at 300°C, they contained ∼60% Pt in the Pto state. Curve 3 (Pt-Ni catalyst) has one pronounced peak with a maximum at 430°C, corresponding to the reduction of PtOx and the shoulder at temperatures below 400°C. This shoulder is related to the peak at 360°C, which is detected at the TPR-H2 of the Ni/HZSM5 sample (curve 1). M.Jordao et al also found two similar reduction peaks, the maximums at 270 and 400 °C for the 1 wt.%Pt/HUSY catalyst calcined at 500 °C, representing the reduction of Pt2+ located in the sodalite cages and the second one located in the hexagonal prisms [43]. In addition, curve 1 shows a pronounced peak in the range of 420−550°C, which probably corresponds to the reduction of larger nickel oxide particles. The simultaneous presence of Pt and Ni ions leads to a decrease in the proportion of these large nickel agglomerates and an overall decrease in the particle size on the surface. Suzuki et al. [44] indicated that there are three reduction peaks at 520°C on Ni/NaY-zeolites TPR diagram, characterizing the reduction of the Ni2+ ions positioned at the three kinds of exchanged sites. It is also obvious that the formation of mixed bimetallic systems (curve 3 in Fig. 4) leads to the disappearance of weakly bound platinum ions. It is these ions that can cause the instability of the active phase in the absence of nickel. A similar phenomenon was observed in catalyst PdNi/HY [45]. According to the authors this behavior may be associated with enhanced recovery of nickel species by interaction with reduced Pd particles and a Pd-Ni ion-pair formation or by nickel ions migration from hexagonal prisms to sodalite cages. The adding of 1.0 wt.% Ni additive led to the enhancement of catalyst property that improves the catalytic activity. PtNi/HZSM-5 catalyst is much more active, selective, and stable in n-hexane hydroisomerization than monometallic Pt catalyst. Specifically, at 250 °C, the n-hexane conversion increased 14%, from 59 to 72%, the selectivity reached 90%, and prolonged the stable operation time (TOS) from 3 hours to 12 hours. From the data of Table 1, it follows that the addition of Ni additive can decrease the cluster size of Pt from 1.63 nm to 1.28 nm, enhance reducibility and acidic density leads to the increase in activity and stability. The kinetic investigation Fig. 5 shows the relaxation curves of changes in the concentration of iso-hexanes 2 (A) and n-hexane (B) in the response of H2/(H2+n-hexane) on Pt (I) catalyst and Pt-Ni (II) sample. As can be seen, the delays in the appearance of isohexanes in the gas phase are greater than the delays for n-hexane, that is, isohexanes are adsorbed on these catalysts more strongly than n-hexanes. The introduction of Ni in the catalyst leads to an increase in these delays, i.e., the strength and/or the amount of adsorbed n-hexane and isohexanes with the surface increases. When the reaction mixture with hydrogen is fed to the surface after purging, these delays are decreased, because it does not take time to displace the hydrogen. Moreover, the delay in the appearance of isohexanes on the Pt-Ni catalyst decreases to a greater extent (from 33 to 26 s.), on the Pt-catalyst, the delay decreases from 28 to 25 s. Delays are decreased to a greater extent if the hydrogen is completely removed from the responses-1 (A). In addition, a comparison of the responses of H2/(H2+n-hexane) -2 (A) and He/(He+n-hexane) -1(A) shows that in the presence of H2, the signal of isohexanes is noticeably higher (results 1 and 2 were obtained sequentially in one experiment, separately for each catalyst). The delays for n-hexane vary to a lesser extent. These results show that hydrogen has a positive effect on the hydroisomerization of n-hexane at a pressure of 1 atm on both the Pt/HZSM-5 and PtNi/HZSM-5 catalysts, hydrogen participates in the isomerization reaction and increases its rate. Data on H2 adsorption on Pt-and Pt-Ni-catalysts are shown in Table 2 . Compared to Pt on Pt-Ni catalyst, the retention time in the appearance of hydrogen in the He/H2 response is shorter; on the contrary, the time to steady state is longer. In the reverse response (H2/He), hydrogen is desorbed faster from the Pt-Ni catalyst. Such differences can be explained by the fact that the total number of adsorption centers for H2 increases after the introduction of nickel, but on the Pt catalyst, hydrogen is more strongly bound, obviously with Pt centers. Meanwhile, the opposite phenomenon was observed on catalyst Pd/HZSM-5, the retention time of hydrogen in a similar response is significantly higher on a nickel-promoted Pd/HZSM-5 than on a catalyst without a promoter [26]. This result confirms the stronger interaction of H2 with Ni than with Pd sites. The conclusions obtained in the non-stationary region complement the results of stationary kinetic studies given below and are important for kinetic modeling. At a constant volume velocity and constant initial concentrations of n-hexane and hydrogen, the rate of isomerization of n-hexane on the catalyst 0.35 Pt/HZSM-5 at 250°C did not depend on the velocity of the circulation flow in the range 20000-70000h−1, i.e., external diffusion did not have a retarding effect on the reaction. Varying the size of the catalyst granules from 0.25−0.6 to 1.00−1.41 mm did not affect the rate of isomerization of n-hexane (Table 3 ). Therefore, it can be assumed that there was no internal-diffusion inhibition on granules <1.41 mm in size. In the research, a granule fraction of 0.25−0.6 mm was used. The results of kinetic studies of the catalysts are shown in tables S1-S2. The change in the rate of isomerization of n-hexane (r) from the temperature in the coordinates of the Arrhenius equation (lnr = f(1/T)) on the studied catalysts with a constant composition of the reaction mixture has a non-linear character (Fig. 6 ), which indicates a fractional rational rather than a power form of the kinetic equation. This is also evidenced by the dependence of 1/r value (r - the isomerization rate) on the partial pressure of iso-hexanes (Fig. 7 A). The introduction of 2-methyl pentane into the reaction mixture resulted in a decrease in the isomerization rate. These dependencies for both systems demonstrate a linear character, i.e. the value of iso-hexanes partial pressure must be included in the denominator of the kinetic equation in the first order. Fig. 7B shows the mono-parameter dependences of the n-hexane isomerization rate on the hydrogen partial pressure. It can be seen that with an increase in the partial pressure of hydrogen, the rate of isomerization increases on both catalysts. The observes were well matched with the results of the unsteady state study in the responses He/(He + n-hexane) and (H2 + n-hexane) above, showing an increase of resulted iso-hexanes in the presence of H2 in the feedstock mixture. The shape of the obtained curves indicates that the "total" order of the partial pressure of hydrogen in the kinetic equation is close to one. The effect of hydrogen in the hydroisomerization is not consistent in the literature. At high reaction pressure (20 atm or more) many studies have determined that the order of H2 is negative, while that of n-hexane is positive on the catalysts Pt/HY [17], Pt/mazzite and Pt/mordenite [27, 28], Pt-W/ZrO2 [19] catalysts. However, the order of hydrogen in the isomerization reaction changes as the reaction pressure changes [20]. In some studies [21-23] the reaction rate is the first order for hydrogen at the pressure of 0.03−2.50 atm on the Pt/SZ catalyst. Even on one catalyst the order for hydrogen could be changed as reaction pressure changes [29]. The concave form of the n-hexane isomerization rate is dependent on the degree of its conversion (the so-called “conversion curves”, the data are obtained under varying flow rates and constant initial conditions) on the Pt and Pt-Ni catalysts at 250°C (Fig. 8 ) indicates that the process is inhibited by isohexane [46]. Thus, the analysis of the experimental data shows that, in general, the observed rate of isomerization of n-hexane should be described by the following kinetic equation (1): (1) r = k P n − C 6 H 14 n 1 P H 2 m 1 γ ( 1 + k 1 P n − C 6 H 14 n 2 + k 2 P H 2 m 2 + k 3 P i − C 6 H 14 m 3 ) 2 α Here k, k1, k2,and k3 - constants, P n − h e x a n e , P H 2 , and P i − h e x a n e - the partial pressures of corresponding compounds, γ - the coefficient of the reaction reversibility [46], α - linearity coefficient [48]. The experimental data, calculated isomerization rates of n-hexane for two models of the kinetic equation, and the standard deviation of these models are given in Table.S1-2. The first model corresponds to the equation proposed for Pd/HZSM5 and Pd-Ni/HZSM5 in our previous work [26], in which the order of the partial pressure of hydrogen in the numerator was determined to be 0.5. The second model differs in that the order of hydrogen in the numerator equal to one. The form of equation (2) is common for describing the isomerization of n-hexane on a Pt- and Pt-Ni-catalyst, but the value of the kinetic constants differs. The calculation of constants and indicators n1, n2, m1, m2, m3, and α was carried out by mathematical selection using spreadsheets. The best agreement between the experimental and calculated data is observed at n1 = n2 = m3 = m1 =1; m2 = α = 0.5 (model-II), i.e. the following kinetic equation is fulfilled (2): (2) r = k P n − h e x a n e P H 2 γ 1 + k 1 P n − h e x a n e + k 2 P H 2 0.5 + k 3 P i − h e x a n e The value α= 0.5 indicated that the reaction takes place in the region of medium surface coverage with adsorbed substances [47]. The values of the constants of equation (2) are given in Table.S3 for two models of kinetic equations. The calculation results in Table.S3 indicated that the adsorption coefficients of n-C6H14 (k1)and i-C6H14 (k3) on the bimetallic catalyst are higher than that on the monometallic one (Pt/HZSM-5), while the hydrogen adsorption coefficient (k2), conversely, on the monometallic catalyst higher. This means that the Ni additive makes the adsorption of the hexanes stronger, while the adsorption of hydrogen is weaker when non-modified and modified catalysts were compared. Furthermore, the adsorption coefficients of i-hexane on both catalysts were higher than that of n-hexane. These results are completely consistent with the conclusions identified in the unsteady state study above. Model II is preferred over model I, on the one hand, due to the much lower standard deviation, on the other hand, in this model the hydrogen adsorption coefficient of promoted catalyst is lower than that of monometallic catalyst, whereas in model I the opposite was observed. In addition, as indicated from Table.S3, the bimetallic catalyst has a higher apparent rate constant (k) of hydroisomerization and lower apparent activation energy of hydroisomerization than the monoplatinum catalyst, theses activation energies are similar for both models. The results obtained and the literature data suggest that the limiting stage of the n-hexane hydroisomerization process is skeletal rearrangement involving adsorbed hydrogen. If we accept the hypothesis of the formation of an unsaturated hydrocarbon after the adsorption of n-hexane, then the limiting step can be described by the following general equation: (3) n − C 6 H 12 Z 1 + 2 H Z 2 = iso − C 6 H 14 Z 1 + 2 Z 2 where Z1 and Z2 are the adsorption centers, which may be identical and/or belong to the active phase and the support. The reaction rate in this case can be written as follows: (4) r = r ( 3 ) = k → × [ n − C 6 H 12 Z 1 ] × [ H Z 2 ] 2 − k ← × [ iso − C 6 H 14 Z 1 ] × [ Z 2 ] 2 where k→ and k← are the constants of the forward and reverse reactions. Obviously, [n-C6H12Z1] ∼ Pn-C 6 H 14 and [HZ2]2 ∼ PH2 and then: (5) r ∼ P n − C 6 H 14 × P H 2 Equation (5) is consistent with the kinetic equation (2), especially if we take into account that: (6) k 1 × P n − C 6 H 14 < < k × P n − C 6 H 14 × P H 2 > > k 2 × P H 2 0.5 Taking into account the limiting stage (3), the following step-schemes can be proposed: Here M – platinum centers, Z - boundary centers of HZSM-5. In Scheme-I: Step 1 - dissociative adsorption of hydrogen at support and platinum centers, step 2 - hydrogen spiller to acid sites of the support, Step 3 - adsorption of n-hexane to platinum centers. The adsorbed n-C6H14, after dehydrogenation in steps 4 and 5, reacts with the boundary centers HZSM-5 and undergoes skeletal rearrangement in step 6. Step 7 is iso-hexane desorption. In this scheme, step 6 is slow and agrees with the kinetic equation proposed above, the remaining steps are fast or equilibrium. In Scheme- II: step 1 - adsorption of n-hexane to sites of the support; step 2 - dissociative adsorption of hydrogen at platinum centers. Step 3 - dissociative adsorption of n-hexane to form a fragment of n-C6H13Z, which dehydrogenated to create fragment n-C6H12Z in the next step. In step 5 producing n-C6H12Z reacts with the HM and undergoes skeletal rearrangement to form iso-C6H14Z. The last step is the desorption of producing iso-C6H14. Both of the proposed schemes are possible, and can be implemented simultaneously, but to different degrees. In this case, scheme I takes into account the adsorption of hydrogen and hexane on the platinum and support centers and the exchange of hydrogen between these centers, and scheme II defines the support centers as the main centers of n-hexane adsorption. It is obvious that the centers of support are quantitatively dominant on the surface and play an important role in the process, while the platinum centers are much smaller, but they bind hydrocarbons and hydrogen more strongly on the surface and increase the speed of the process as a whole. In addition, it is possible to transfer not only hydrogen, but also adsorbed hydrocarbon fragments from the M to Z centers. Thus, a more rigorous description of the stages requires a deeper understanding of the nature of the active centers and intermediate states on the surface of the catalysts. Conclusions The introduction of Ni into Pt/HZSM-5 leads to an increase in the rate of hydroisomerization of n-hexane and the time of stable work. Important positive factors of nickel influence on Pt/HZSM-5 are the decreasing of the Pt-clusters size, the stabilization of the active phase, the increasing of the hydrogen surface concentration under reaction conditions and a decrease in the activation energy of n-hexane isomerization. The results show that the kinetics of the n-hexane hydroisomerization reaction on Pt-based catalysts is described by a common kinetic equation, following the Langmuir Hinshelwood mechanism with the surface skeletal rearrangement of n-hexene fragment by hydrogen adsorbed was the rate-controlling step. Thus, for Pt/HZSM5 and Pt-Ni/HZSM5, fractional rational kinetic equations of hydroisomerization of n-hexane, differing in the value of constants, were obtained. Hydrogen, which cannot be considered as a stoichiometric component, whose role is limited only to preventing the deactivation of the catalyst due to coke formation, directly participates in the n-hexane isomerization reaction, increasing its rate. Comparison of supported platinum and palladium catalysts shows that on platinum catalysts the rate of isomerization of n-hexane at high temperatures is higher than on palladium catalysts. A positive difference between platinum catalysts is the higher dispersion of the active phase. A positive factor of Pd-Ni/HZSM-5 is the low activation energy of n-hexane isomerization, compared to Pt-Ni/HZSM-5, the effect of which becomes noticeable at temperatures below 250°C.
